Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences in Computer Science for Students at Undergraduate Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding renews a long-running and highly-successful CISE Research
Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at DePauw University. The
site exposes students to a range of topics in Computer Science, including
pen-based computing, computer-supported cooperative work, assistive
technology, natural language processing, functional programming
languages, wireless sensor networks, programming pedagogy, parallel
programming, and virtual reality. Students will work in small teams
with a mentor and will experience conducting research as part of a team,
disseminating research results, and participating in a community of
scholars.

This REU site will allow 24 students (over three years) to experience
research in a variety of areas in Computer Science. The site focuses
on recruiting students from undergraduate-only institutions, who do not
have as ready access to research opportunities as students at research
universities. The site?s primary objective is to encourage talented
students enrolled at undergraduate institutions to pursue graduate
studies and research careers in Computer Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided money to allow twenty-four students (eight per summer over three summers) to perform research in computer science topics. Our primary goal was to encourage talented undergraduate students to pursue graduate study and/or research careers in computer science. We focused on our attention on students that might not have as many opportunities for research as others; thus, we limited our applications to students at institutions with no graduate programs in computer science.

Our students performed research projects in areas such as autonomous vehicle navigation, parallel programming, artificial intelligence, social networks, computer security, and using technology (including Google Glass) in the classroom. The students published their work in papers and research posters, and presented their work in conferences across the country. There were two papers published and six conference and symposium presentations of research posters from the twelve projects (typically four projects per summer, two students per project). The other projects presented their work at a DePauw student poster presentation session.

During their summer at DePauw, the students all lived together in student housing, and they participated in numerous social activities in addition to research. In addition, each summer we traveled to a regional graduate school to see what graduate school is really like. Our students could talk to "real" graduate students and faculty to see what they could expect if they attended graduate school themselves.

Of the twenty-four students, ten of the students are either still pursuing undergraduate studies or have just graduated (and not informed us of their plans). Of the remaining fourteen students, four of them are pursuing advanced degrees in graduate school.
